Based on my search, here are the relevant results for UXP plugin range input slider examples with CSS:

## UXP Plugin Range Input Slider Information

### Adobe UXP-Specific Resources

There are various code samples available with links to starter projects that should help you get started quickly with your idea and develop a plugin for Photoshop in UXP. The samples are all available on GitHub.(no content)Photoshop provides light and dark themes. Using Spectrum UXP, you can access the Photoshop colors to make your UI look as native as possible.(no content)In UXP, you can use native elements like the range slider, though they're not very fancy looking. The Spectrum slider looks nicer, so you should use Spectrum components where possible because this will keep the look consistent and Adobe keeps refining those components.(no content)There's a discussion on the Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums about using the Spectrum CSS "Slider Range" Component in a non-React UXP PS panel.

### General CSS Range Slider Styling

The fastest way to create a custom range slider is to use CSS pseudo-elements like `.slider::-webkit-slider-thumb` and `.slider::-moz-range-thumb` to customize the appearance, width, height, background color, and cursor.(no content)Creating a custom input range slider is achieved by using CSS to override the default browser styles. The key is to target specific pseudo-elements like `::-webkit-slider-runnable-track` for the slider's track and `::-webkit-slider-thumb` for its handle, while using vendor-prefixed versions for cross-browser compatibility. This allows for complete control over the appearance, from colors and sizes to custom thumb icons.(no content)The most important step is to use `-webkit-appearance: none;` to remove the native styling, giving you a blank canvas.

### Key Resources

- **Adobe UXP Code Samples**: https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/guides/code_samples/
- **Adobe UXP Developer Forums**: https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/question-about-spectrum-css-slider-range-component/2275
- **W3Schools Range Slider Tutorial**: https://www.w3schools.com/howto/howto_js_rangeslider.asp
- **MDN Input Range Documentation**: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Elements/input/range


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Adobe","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/uxp-api/known-issues/"},{"title":"UXP 2 to 3 · Adobe XD Plugin Reference","url":"https://adobexdplatform.com/plugin-docs/migrations/uxp-2-to-3.html"},{"title":"Question about Spectrum CSS \"Slider Range\" Component - UXP Plugin API - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/question-about-spectrum-css-slider-range-component/2275"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #1 Rundown on the UXP announcement | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know"},{"title":"uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples/ui-kitchen-sink/index.html at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples/blob/main/ui-kitchen-sink/index.html"},{"title":"Code Samples—UXP for Adobe Photoshop","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/guides/code_samples/"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #9 Adobe Spectrum | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/Adobe-UXP-things-you-need-to-know-9-Adobe-Spectrum-UXP.html"},{"title":"Sliders · Adobe XD Plugin Reference","url":"https://adobexdplatform.com/plugin-docs/reference/ui/elements/sliders.html"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #2 Documentation | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know-2-documentation"},{"title":"Range select slider - UXP Plugin API - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/range-select-slider/1120"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe UXP slider and CSS range input:

## Slider Options in Adobe UXP

There are two main approaches to implementing sliders in UXP:

### 1. Native HTML Range Input
Sliders allow the user to pick from a continuum of values between a minimum and maximum value. Slider values are continuous by default, but may be discrete if desired (using the step attribute).

Example usage from the documentation:
```html
<input type="range" min=0 max=100 value=50 />
```

However, there's a known limitation: Sliders do not receive keyboard or pointer events.

### 2. Spectrum UXP Slider (`sp-slider`)
You can use the Spectrum slider component with syntax like: `<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50"><sp-label slot="label">Slider Label</sp-label></sp-slider>`(no content)You could use native elements like the native range slider, but the Spectrum slider is "kind of nicer." It's recommended to use Spectrum components where possible because this will keep the look consistent and they are keeping refining those components.

### CSS Considerations

Using unitless values in width and height attributes are not supported in UXP v3.1.0. Use px, or CSS styles.(no content)You can use CSS media queries with sliders, for example: `@media screen and (max-width: 260px) { input[type=range] { display: none; } }` - this CSS will hide sliders whenever the plugin's viewport width is less than 260px.

### Key Known Issues
- HTML5 input validation is not supported.
- At the moment you're free to use HTML native "form" elements like `<select>`, `<textarea>`, `<input>` etc. They're decently styled, but be aware that in the long run those HTML native elements will be deprecated in favor of their Spectrum UXP widgets counterparts.

For best compatibility and future-proofing, using `sp-slider` (Spectrum UXP slider) is recommended over the native `<input type="range">`.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
# Analysis of Slider Code Examples in UXP Plugins

Based on the provided forum content, **no actual code examples are present** in this discussion thread.

## What the Thread Contains

The discussion references Spectrum CSS slider documentation but does not include implementation code. The key points are:

- **Current Support**: "Spectrum UXP supports `sp-slider`, but does _not_ yet support the `range` feature" (kerrishotts, Nov 30, 2020)

- **Limitation**: The range slider functionality described in Adobe's Spectrum CSS documentation is not available for non-React UXP Photoshop panels at the time of this discussion

- **Workaround Suggested**: Users "could probably build a custom control that does this, but that would require a bit of work"

## Missing Resources

No HTML, CSS, or JavaScript code examples for range sliders are provided in this thread. To find working implementations, you would need to:

1. Consult the official Spectrum CSS documentation directly
2. Review Adobe's UXP plugin samples repository
3. Check more recent forum posts (this thread is from 2020-2022)

The discussion focuses on feature requests rather than functional code demonstrations.

content.content:
# Slider HTML Code Examples

Based on the kitchen sink UI sample, here are the slider implementations:

## Spectrum Sliders (sp-slider)

**Basic slider:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50"></sp-slider>
```

**Disabled slider:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50" disabled></sp-slider>
```

**Slider with label:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50">
  <sp-label slot="label">Slider Label</sp-label>
</sp-slider>
```

**Filled variant:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50" variant="filled"></sp-slider>
```

**Filled and disabled:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50" variant="filled" disabled></sp-slider>
```

## Native HTML Range Input

```html
<label>Opacity: <input type="range" min="0" max="100" value="50"></label>
```

The Spectrum sliders accept `min`, `max`, and `value` attributes, support optional `disabled` and `variant="filled"` states, and can include labeled text via the `slot="label"` mechanism.

toolUseResult.result:
# Slider HTML Code Examples

Based on the kitchen sink UI sample, here are the slider implementations:

## Spectrum Sliders (sp-slider)

**Basic slider:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50"></sp-slider>
```

**Disabled slider:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50" disabled></sp-slider>
```

**Slider with label:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50">
  <sp-label slot="label">Slider Label</sp-label>
</sp-slider>
```

**Filled variant:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50" variant="filled"></sp-slider>
```

**Filled and disabled:**
```html
<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50" variant="filled" disabled></sp-slider>
```

## Native HTML Range Input

```html
<label>Opacity: <input type="range" min="0" max="100" value="50"></label>
```

The Spectrum sliders accept `min`, `max`, and `value` attributes, support optional `disabled` and `variant="filled"` states, and can include labeled text via the `slot="label"` mechanism.

Web search results for query: "sp-slider UXP CSS styling custom range input Premiere Pro plugin"

Links: [{"title":"CSS styling","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/recipes/css-styling/"},{"title":"Question about Spectrum CSS \"Slider Range\" Component - UXP Plugin API - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/question-about-spectrum-css-slider-range-component/2275"},{"title":"Style SP-SLIDER, SP-PICKER and SP-SWITCH with CSS - UXP Plugin API - Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums","url":"https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/style-sp-slider-sp-picker-and-sp-switch-with-css/4271"},{"title":"Building your first UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/"},{"title":"sp-slider","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/xd/uxp/uxp/reference-spectrum/User%20Interface/sp-slider/"},{"title":"Creating a custom CSS range slider with JavaScript upgrades - LogRocket Blog","url":"https://blog.logrocket.com/creating-custom-css-range-slider-javascript-upgrades/"},{"title":"uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples/ui-kitchen-sink/index.html at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples/blob/main/ui-kitchen-sink/index.html"},{"title":"37 CSS Range Slider Examples | FreeFrontend","url":"https://freefrontend.com/css-range-sliders/"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #9 Adobe Spectrum | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know-9-adobe-spectrum-uxp"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #1 Rundown on the UXP announcement | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know"}]

Based on my search results, here's what I found about sp-slider UXP CSS styling for custom range input in Premiere Pro plugins:

## Key Findings

### CSS Styling in UXP
Spectrum is Adobe's design system, used across multiple applications. Adobe recommends using Spectrum-based controls wherever possible for UI consistency. UXP offers a ready-made Spectrum-styled UI library.(no content)While exploring importing a stylesheet or making tweaks, you should keep in mind that UXP is not a browser. Its architecture does not (and will not) support all CSS properties. For example, UXP cannot support grid layout innately. The ones that are supported are listed in the API reference docs.(no content)In plugins, you have a lot more flexibility to manage CSS styling. You can add it via CSS classes or use inline styling or add it via JavaScript.

### sp-slider Component
The sp-slider fills one side of the slider track, with the side specified via fill-offset. You can specify a custom unit for the slider value (such as "%"), and you can hide the slider value.

### Styling Challenges with Spectrum Components
There's a question about whether there's a way to style elements of SP-SLIDER, SP-PICKER and SP-SWITCH with CSS. For example, changing the color of handler in slider or the highlight color for SP-PICKER (which is blue by default).

### Spectrum vs Native Elements
You can use native elements, but they're not very fancy looking. For instance, the native range slider is available, but the Spectrum slider is "kind of nicer." You should use Spectrum components where possible because this will keep the look consistent and Adobe keeps refining those components.

### Web Components and Shadow DOM
Spectrum Web Components are Web Components that follow the Spectrum specs. Generally speaking, a web component is a reusable custom HTML element that encapsulates a Shadow DOM (a hidden DOM tree that is rendered separately from the Document's DOM tree) with its own set of styles and behavior.

### Example Usage
An example of sp-slider usage: `<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50" disabled><sp-label slot="label">Slider Label - Disabled</sp-label></sp-slider>`

### CSS Preprocessors
UXP understands pure CSS only. Using CSS preprocessors such as SASS or SCSS is possible, provided you transpile your code to a CSS stylesheet before using it.

The forum discussion at Creative Cloud Developer Forums suggests that styling sp-slider components with custom CSS (like changing handler colors) may be limited due to the Shadow DOM encapsulation of these Spectrum web components.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
# CSS Styling Solutions for SP-SLIDER

Based on the provided forum content, **there are no CSS styling solutions or code examples documented for customizing sp-slider appearance**.

## Key Findings:

The original question asks: "Is there a way to style elements of SP-SLIDER, SP-PICKER and SP-SWITCH with CSS?" The user specifically wanted to "change the colour of handler in slider or the highlight colour for SP-PICKER."

**However, the thread provides no answers.** The discussion that follows focuses instead on:
- Confusion about component availability and naming
- Notes that some components are deprecated or not fully functional in UXP
- References to workarounds for sp-picker in a separate thread

## Recommendation:

The original poster explicitly states: "I was looking for the reference but I can't find any." This suggests official CSS customization documentation for these Spectrum components is either unavailable or not readily accessible through the Adobe UXP documentation at the time of posting (February 2022).

To find current styling guidance, you would need to consult the official Adobe UXP plugin API documentation or explore the Spectrum CSS framework specifications directly.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP plugin input range slider drag events:

## UXP Slider Drag Event Information

### The Problem
A common issue with UXP spectrum sliders is getting them to update on value change as it slides before mouse up. Currently, sliders change values but only run the function after the mouse button is released, not as the value changes.

### Standard Usage with `sp-slider`
The Adobe UXP documentation shows the basic slider syntax: `<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50"><sp-label slot="label">Slider Label</sp-label></sp-slider>`

### Event Listener Approach
The typical approach uses: `document.querySelector("#//siderId").addEventListener("change", //functionName);`

### Known Limitations
The `input` event doesn't seem to respond to changes in UXP sliders. The `change` event works as expected but only shows the effect on mouse up. The mouseup event has the same behavior as change but seems to miss changes occasionally.

### XD's Behavior
For UI events that often occur in rapid-fire clusters, such as dragging a slider or pressing keys in a text field, XD tries to smartly merge consecutive edits into a single atomic Undo step.

### Resources for Examples
Adobe provides various code samples with links to starter projects. These samples are all available on GitHub where you can clone or fork them.

The GitHub repository at `AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples` contains a UI kitchen sink example with slider implementations. Unfortunately, getting real-time updates during drag (before mouseup) appears to be a known limitation in UXP's spectrum slider component, and developers have reported that the standard `input` event doesn't work as expected for continuous updates during dragging.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

For UI events that often occur in rapid-fire clusters, such as dragging a slider or pressing keys in a text field, XD tries to smartly merge consecutive edits into a single atomic Undo step.

# Range Slider Implementation in UXP

Based on the provided content, **no code examples or solutions are actually included** in this forum discussion.

## What the Page Contains

The page is a feature request discussion where user **mightyalex** asks for range slider functionality:

> "It would be great if the Slider element could support range select i.e. capture a range of two from-to values with two drag handles."

The request references a jQuery UI range slider example (shown as an image), but no actual implementation code is provided in the thread.

## Available Resources

The page mentions several related discussions:
- "Vanilla Four Handle Slider"
- "Question about Spectrum CSS 'Slider Range' Component"
- "Double handle slider"

However, the content excerpted here doesn't include the technical details or code from those related topics.

## Conclusion

To find actual HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code for UXP range slider implementation, you would need to:
1. Visit the linked related topics
2. Check Adobe's official UXP documentation
3. Review the Spectrum CSS component documentation referenced in the discussions

content.content:
# UXP Slider Real-Time Update Solutions

## Event Listener Approaches

**Input Event (Limited Success):**
```javascript
document.querySelector("#sliderId").addEventListener("input", functionName);
```
The `input` event fires during dragging, but Photoshop won't update the canvas while the mouse button is held down.

**Change Event (Mouse Up Only):**
```javascript
document.querySelector("#sliderId").addEventListener("change", functionName);
```
Only triggers after mouse release, not during dragging.

## BatchPlay Configuration (Most Effective)

According to the discussion, adding specific flags to your BatchPlay object can enable real-time updates:

```javascript
"synchronousExecution": true,
"modalBehavior": "execute",
"paintOptions": {
    "immediateUpdate": true,
    "quality": "draft"
}
```

As one developer noted, the `"paintOptions"` values specify draft quality rendering with immediate updates, which "fixed it for me."

## Key Limitation

Photoshop has a fundamental constraint: "PS will not update while the mouse button is down." The `input` event processes UI changes in your panel during drag, but Photoshop doesn't extend that to its canvas until mouse release—regardless of event type used.

The BatchPlay `paintOptions` approach appears to be the most reliable workaround documented in this forum thread.

toolUseResult.result:
# UXP Slider Real-Time Update Solutions

## Event Listener Approaches

**Input Event (Limited Success):**
```javascript
document.querySelector("#sliderId").addEventListener("input", functionName);
```
The `input` event fires during dragging, but Photoshop won't update the canvas while the mouse button is held down.

**Change Event (Mouse Up Only):**
```javascript
document.querySelector("#sliderId").addEventListener("change", functionName);
```
Only triggers after mouse release, not during dragging.

## BatchPlay Configuration (Most Effective)

According to the discussion, adding specific flags to your BatchPlay object can enable real-time updates:

```javascript
"synchronousExecution": true,
"modalBehavior": "execute",
"paintOptions": {
    "immediateUpdate": true,
    "quality": "draft"
}
```

As one developer noted, the `"paintOptions"` values specify draft quality rendering with immediate updates, which "fixed it for me."

## Key Limitation

Photoshop has a fundamental constraint: "PS will not update while the mouse button is down." The `input` event processes UI changes in your panel during drag, but Photoshop doesn't extend that to its canvas until mouse release—regardless of event type used.

The BatchPlay `paintOptions` approach appears to be the most reliable workaround documented in this forum thread.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about UXP sp-slider value attribute binding and JavaScript updates:

## UXP sp-slider Overview

The basic syntax for sp-slider in UXP is: `<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50"><sp-label slot="label">Slider Label</sp-label></sp-slider>`

### Event Handling

A common issue with UXP sliders is that they only run the function after the mouse button is released, not as the value changes. The typical approach is calling code with `document.querySelector("#sliderId").addEventListener("change", functionName);`(no content)Users have asked if it's possible to get a spectrum slider to update on the value change as it slides before mouse up.

### Slider Features

The sp-slider fills one side of the slider track, which side is specified with `fill-offset`.(no content)You can specify a custom unit for the slider value (such as "%"), and you can also hide the slider value.

### Using Spectrum Components

You don't need to import or load anything in your projects in order to use Spectrum UXP components: they are available straight away, just use them in your HTML.(no content)You can use native elements like the range slider, but the Spectrum slider looks nicer. You should use Spectrum components where possible because this will keep the look consistent and they are keeping refining those components.

### Code Resources

Adobe provides various code samples with links to starter projects that should help you get started quickly with developing a plugin for Photoshop in UXP. The samples are all available on GitHub.

For real-time value updates while sliding (before mouseup), you may need to listen to the `input` event instead of `change`, though support for this in UXP may vary depending on the version.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## UXP sp-slider Overview

The basic syntax for sp-slider in UXP is: `<sp-slider min="0" max="100" value="50"><sp-label slot="label">Slider Label</sp-label></sp-slider>`

### Event Handling

A common issue with UXP sliders is that they only run the function after the mouse button is released, not as the value changes. The typical approach is calling code with `document.querySelector("#sliderId").addEventListener("change", functionName);`(no content)Users have asked if it's possible to get a spectrum slider to update on the value change as it slides before mouse up.

### Slider Features

The sp-slider fills one side of the slider track, which side is specified with `fill-offset`.(no content)You can specify a custom unit for the slider value (such as "%"), and you can also hide the slider value.

For real-time value updates while sliding (before mouseup), you may need to listen to the `input` event instead of `change`, though support for this in UXP may vary depending on the version.

Links: [{"title":"Adobe","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/xd/uxp/uxp/reference-css/Pseudo-classes/root/"},{"title":"CSS styling","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/recipes/css-styling/"},{"title":"Pseudo-elements","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/uxp-api/reference-css/Pseudo-elements/"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #9 Adobe Spectrum | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know-9-adobe-spectrum-uxp"},{"title":"API Changelog","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/changelog/"},{"title":"UXP 2 to 3 · Adobe XD Plugin Reference","url":"https://adobexdplatform.com/plugin-docs/migrations/uxp-2-to-3.html"},{"title":"Adobe UXP: Things you need to know! #2 Documentation | Davide Barranca — Photoshop, etc.","url":"https://www.davidebarranca.com/development/adobe-uxp-things-you-need-to-know-2-documentation"},{"title":"Documentation-UXP for Adobe Photoshop","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2021/"},{"title":"Making your Plugin Theme-aware","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/guides/theme-awareness/"},{"title":"UXP API Reference","url":"https://adobedocs.github.io/uxp-photoshop/uxp-api/"}]

Here's what I found about Adobe UXP CSS supported properties, pseudo-elements, and slider:

## UXP CSS Support Overview

While you are exploring importing a stylesheet or making tweaks, you should keep in mind that UXP is not a browser. Its architecture does not (and will not) support all the CSS properties. For example, UXP cannot support grid layout innately.(no content)CSS properties, Browser API or HTML elements must be willingly implemented by the UXP team, and priorities must be given. So for instance we've got CSS FlexBox, but not CSS Grids yet.

## Pseudo-elements Support

UXP supports pseudo-elements including `::after`, `::before`, and `::width`.(no content)UXP also supports `pointer-events: none` CSS property and pseudoElement in the `getComputedStyle(element, pseudoElement)` API.(no content)Added support for `:first-child` and `:not(:first-child)` pseudo-classes to enhance the existing Web Component support, and support for the `linear-gradient` property with start and end values.

## Slider and updateUI

If you are looking to refresh the Layers panel while dragging a slider handle, try `updateUI()`.

## CSS Variables and Additional Features

UXP 3.1 supports CSS variables, additional units, calc, limited Media Queries, !important, and more.(no content)The easiest way to make your plugin theme-aware is to make use of CSS variables. Photoshop exposes a number of theme-specific CSS variables that are perfect for making your plugin respond to the user's theme color choice.

## CSS Reference Documentation

The UXP documentation includes CSS reference covering general variables, units, the "calc" function, selectors, media queries, pseudo elements, pseudo classes, and styles.(no content)The CSS Reference provides technical documentation regarding the kinds of CSS styles and features available in UXP.

For the complete list of supported CSS properties and pseudo-elements, you can visit the official Adobe UXP documentation at developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

input.prompt: List all supported pseudo-elements in UXP. Check if webkit-slider-thumb or moz-range-thumb are supported.
Extract all code examples for sp-slider and slider usage in UXP, including HTML syntax, attributes, and event handling.

content.content:
# sp-slider Usage in UXP

Based on the article, here's the extracted information about sp-slider implementation:

## HTML Syntax

The basic structure shown in the sample code:

```html
<sp-slider variant="filled" min="1" max="10" value="3" id="order">
  <sp-label slot="label">How many T-Shirts do you want?</sp-label>
</sp-slider>
```

## Key Attributes

- `variant="filled"` - Creates a filled appearance where "the left part of the run is a different color"
- `min` - Minimum value
- `max` - Maximum value
- `value` - Default/current value
- `id` - Element identifier for JavaScript access

## Event Handling

Retrieve slider values via standard DOM queries:

```javascript
let order = document.querySelector("#order").value;
```

## Important Notes

The article mentions that not all Spectrum widgets support T-Shirt sizing. The slider component uses standard numeric attributes rather than the size attribute available on typography elements like `<sp-heading>`.

The slider must be closed with a closing tag `</sp-slider>`, particularly important when using the component with React.js frameworks.

toolUseResult.result:
# sp-slider Usage in UXP

Based on the article, here's the extracted information about sp-slider implementation:

## HTML Syntax

The basic structure shown in the sample code:

```html
<sp-slider variant="filled" min="1" max="10" value="3" id="order">
  <sp-label slot="label">How many T-Shirts do you want?</sp-label>
</sp-slider>
```

## Key Attributes

- `variant="filled"` - Creates a filled appearance where "the left part of the run is a different color"
- `min` - Minimum value
- `max` - Maximum value
- `value` - Default/current value
- `id` - Element identifier for JavaScript access

## Event Handling

Retrieve slider values via standard DOM queries:

```javascript
let order = document.querySelector("#order").value;
```

## Important Notes

The article mentions that not all Spectrum widgets support T-Shirt sizing. The slider component uses standard numeric attributes rather than the size attribute available on typography elements like `<sp-heading>`.

The slider must be closed with a closing tag `</sp-slider>`, particularly important when using the component with React.js frameworks.
